paddle_tips.name: How to communicate and trust your partner at the net
paddle_tips.description: A strong partnership is the foundation of success in platform tennis, especially at the net. This week, focus on improving communication and positioning with your partner by keeping these key points in mind:DonÕt Take Balls Over Your Left Shoulder: If youÕre on the right side of the court, avoid attempting to hit balls that are over your left shoulder. These shots are awkward, low-percentage, and often leave you out of position. Trust your partner on the left to take those balls with their forehand or overhead for a more effective play.Call Your Position on the Right: As the player on the right side, it's crucial to communicate your positioning during play. Let your partner know when youÕre covering the middle or holding your ground to avoid confusion and overlap. Clear, decisive calls like "Mine!" or "Yours!" build confidence and prevent costly errors.Stay in the Circle of Trust: Imagine a "circle of trust" between you and your partnerÑthis is the space where you confidently trust each other to cover your zones. Avoid overreaching or second-guessing your partnerÕs decisions, as it disrupts team synergy and can lead to missed opportunities.By focusing on these fundamentals, youÕll build better court coverage and a stronger team dynamic. Trust the system and your partner to win more points together!Please click on the link below for an amazing breakdown of a " Circle of Trust" positioning. Use volume because video has great explanation with it!

paddle_tips.name: How to blitz
paddle_tips.description: Let's talk about BLITZING! The purpose of blitzing is to surprise the opponents, apply pressure, and force them into making a rushed or defensive shot. HereÕs why players choose to blitz:Blitzing on a lob is a high-risk, high-reward tactic. This strategy can work well in specific situations and offers several advantages, but it also requires precise timing and good positioning. Please click on the link below for an amazing breakdown Blitz on The Lob Video!CLICK HEREBlitzing is most effective when timed well, executed with speed, and followed by sharp volleys or overheads. However, it carries some risk, as a poor blitz can leave your team vulnerable to a lob or a well-placed drive.Exploit Weak Serve: If the opponents often hit high or short serve, blitzing allows you to capitalize with a volley or overhead.Pressure Opponents: By rushing the net, you force the opponents to make quick decisions, increasing the chances of errors or weaker shots.Variety and Unpredictability: Mixing in blitzing keeps your strategy unpredictable, making it harder for opponents to anticipate your moves.Team Synergy: A well-coordinated blitz with your partner can help maintain aggressive momentum and cover the court effectively.

paddle_tips.name: How to keep your opponent out of the ktchen
paddle_tips.description: Keep Your Opponents Out of the Kitchen!This week we focus on the baseline team. Specifically, the quality of their lobs and their shot selection in an effort to take advantage of their net opponents. In the image above, the area shaded in RED would be the kitchen if these four people were playing pickleball.  In Paddle, of course, there is no kitchen. There are no rules stopping you from getting close to, or on top of, the net. Therefore, it is your job to keep as the baseline team to keep your opponents back from the net. This means it's very important to work on the quality of your lobs. The lobs don't have to be perfect, but they must be good enough to keep your opponents in the back half of the service box. This stops them from punishing you with overheads into the corner, and increases the probability of them making a mistake or leaving you a short ball to drive. Furthermore, it is important to also consider lobbing even when you have a drive opportunity if your opponents are inside the kitchen.  DO NOT DRIVE AT YOUR OPPONENTS WHEN THEY ARE CLOSE TO THE NET.

paddle_tips.name: How to drive
paddle_tips.description: This week we will focus on the appropriate time to drive the ball, and where to drive it. We will also discuss lobbing a "drivable" ball when the net team is in good volley position. Keep in mind, any time you hit a great lob (as shown below) you should move into a drive ready position. This means getting your toes up near the baseline and setting your preferred shot (forehand vs backhand). This does not mean you are obligated to drive, it simply means you are prepared to execute the drive if the overhead lands in the right spot for you (short and to your preferred drive stroke.

paddle_tips.name: How to a avoide the deuce side disaster
paddle_tips.description: What happens when you hit the overhead to the deuce side corner (red arrow)? DEUCE SIDE DISASTER!When you an your partner are OFF the net, keep the overhead deep and to the middle 60% of the court (NO ANGLES!) OPTIONS:Go to the deuce player's backhandGo to the AD player's bodyDO NOT GO TO THE DEUCE CORNER!CLICK HERE AND WATCHThis week we avoid the DEUCE SIDE disaster.  What is it?You are at the netYou and your partner are setting up to hit your overheads to the middle and AD corner (first image shows the ideal formation for you and your partner at the net)For some CRAZY REASON, you hit the overhead towards the DEUCE CORNER...NOT GOOD!If you are closer to the net when hitting your overhead, you have the option to hit the ball to the AD side corner screen (shown above).Again, hitting to the middle OR the AD corner (yellow arrows) keeps the ball in front of you and your partner and allows you to keep your ideal positioning at the net with the player on the left near the "T" (middle of the court).  RED ARROW(S) When you hit to the deuce corner, it not only gives your opponent an opening down the line (lob or drive), but also forces you and your partner to shift to the left half of the court. This shift causes some major issues/confusion as it pulls the player on the left away from the middle of the court and the roles (overheader vs drive stopper) are less defined.

paddle_tips.name: How to serve and first volley
paddle_tips.description: Your serve is like ordering coffee:_you don't need to get fancy with it - just reliable and strong enough get things going. Keep it consistent, not too hot (or too fast), or your opponents will send it right back before you even take a sip.
